comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Mr Spooner is your man for details of the London Clown Cricketers...

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/lincsranger64/5078744883/]

Yesterday by chance I came across an account of a cricket match played on the Northolme in 1851.
It appeared in the Hull Packet and East Riding Times on July 18th 1851, and in 1874 a rather bizarre-sounding match took place there - 13 London Clown Cricketers against 16 of Gainsborough and district.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content:
Excellent record and very rare photograph of this tram system - 'Cork City Tramways', as Nail says, it was only in operation for four years, Sept 1872 to Dec 1875.

The idea was to link the three railway termini as the destinations imply; Albert St (Cork Blackrock & Passage), Albert Quay (Cork & Bandon) and Glanmire Rd (Great Southern & Western) and the 5 ft 3in gauge and track used was supposed to allow goods wagons to be hauled between the goods depots at each station but this never happened. 
It operated a circuitous route without reaching the suburbs and the track was inconvenient and unsightly within the city centre. 

On its demise, the six Starbuck and Birkenhead manufactured trams were sold to Dublin, the photograph featuring the last, No.6, constructed. When trams returned to Cork they were electric.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Cricket in Lansdowne Road Ger Siggins 11 August 2010 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- CricketEurope columnist Ger Siggins has collaborated with his Sunday Tribune colleague Malachy Clerkin on a new book on the history of Lansdowne Road. While the stadium is known the world over for the epic rugby and soccer contests that have graced its turf, they aren’t the only sports to featured there. American Football, Lacrosse, Baseball, Athletics and Pigeon Shooting were among the games played in the stadium, which was originally conceived as a multi-sports club. And for the first 20 years cricket was a vital part of the mix as Ger Siggins explains in this exclusive extract from ‘Lansdowne Road: The Stadium, The Matches, The Greatest Days’…. Back in August 1874 cricket was still arguably the most widely played game in the land. Henry Dunlop had ambitions to challenge the supremacy of the Trinity club in its staging of lucrative annual matches against touring sides and English counties, and teamed up with publisher and sports goods seller John Lawrence to invite over the London Imperial Clowns for games against Eleven Gentlemen of Ireland. It was a raucous Victorian version of Twenty20, with the Clowns being actual circus performers, augmented by some useful professionals. The Gentlemen of Ireland was a strong selection, with several of the best players of the day, including celebrated scholar and wit JP Mahaffy, who taught Oscar Wilde; and Leland Hone, who later played test matches for England. The play was interspersed with musical interludes while the Clowns entertained the audience with acrobatic fielding. The Irish Times man was unimpressed: ‘Many lovers of cricket objected to their game being burlesqued, and consequently absented themselves from a match where they expected nothing but buffoonery.’ Not quite so generous was the man from Saunders Newsletter, who thought ‘We may content ourselves now by hoping we ne’er may look upon its like again. Buffoonery, through the medium of cricket, may amuse the village Yokels, or create a laugh in the circus, but we doubt much whether Irish gentlemen will again be found arrayed against such competitors in such costume.’ Sadly for Lawrence, there was little spectator interest in such frivolity either, and the weather was no help: the attendance was described as ‘wretched’. He lost £100 on his promotion, which was not repeated. Ironically, Dunlop’s rivals at the Leinster club put up a purse to attract the greatest cricketer of the age, W.G. Grace, who brought a huge crowd to Rathmines for a proper match a few weeks later. From Cricket Europe - Ireland

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: The Mardyke is the home ground of Cork County Cricket Club, who have played there since their formation in 1874

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] I knew they sounded familiar. There's an account in Freeman's of the match played against 11 Gentlemen of Ireland at Lansdowne Road starting on 17th August 1874 (described by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06]). In short, they were accomplished cricketers, but dressed in clown outfits, and "they made their folly the stalking horse for their wisdom". It is suggested the Irishmen may have been put off by their antics. Freeman's account of the first day's play But nothing about any games in Cork. BTW I played football on (the hallowed turf of ) The Northolme 99 years after the London Clown Cricketers played there.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Here we are: The Era (London, England), Sunday, August 30, 1874
MUNSTER HALL (Proprietors, Messrs MacCarthy and Scanlan) - The London Clown Cricketers were here on Monday and Tuesday last, and played a match with the Cork County Cricket Club, which was witnessed by a large concourse of people. In the evening of each day they gave an entertainment in the above Hall before very large and respectable audiences.

comment.author: 60812213@N04
comment._content: The square building across the river on the left, is the second goods depot for the Penrose Quay GSWR station. The line went straight into it from the tunnel. Later, when Kent station was built, the trains entered from the east side of the building. I can also see construction on the lower road, perhaps building the road bridge over the line. Previously a level crossing existed.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Had a look at a book on sport in Cork this morning. No mention of this in the cricket section, and the fact that Cork Cricket Club had just been set up the year before makes the Clown Cricketers' visit to Cork in 1874 even more of a big deal...
